title: Natural Language-Driven Automation for Network Device Management with Large Language Models
authors: Hasbian Alif, Yulius Denny Prabowo, Viga Laksa Hardjanto
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Emerging Trends in Information Systems and Informatics (ICETISI)
abstract: An optimized network infrastructure is essential for ensuring the reliability, security, and growth of IT-based businesses. However, operating network devices often requires advanced technical knowledge, which can become a significant barrier for non-technical users, particularly in large-scale networks. This study presents the development of a web-based network automation application utilizing Natural Language Processing (NLP) to minimize dependency on deep technical expertise in network operations. Using Python, Netmiko, and the OpenAI API, the system translates natural language commands into executable network actions. Experimental evaluation consisting of 30 test cases shows that the system successfully executed the intended function calls in 27 cases (90% success rate). User interface latency was recorded between 2 and 10 seconds, while device connection times ranged from 3 to 5 seconds. All reported values are based on direct measurement during controlled functional testing. These results demonstrate that NLP-based automation can effectively simplify network operations, improve accessibility, and enhance efficiency in managing network infrastructure.

title: Evaluating the Out-of-Distribution Generalization of Robot Diffusion Policies under the DINOv2 Visual Encoder
authors: Ángel Montejo, Iñigo Iturrate
publish: 2026 IEEE/SICE International Symposium on System Integration (SII)
abstract: The generalizability of visuomotor policy models is crucial for their real-world usefulness in settings such as industrial environments. This is heavily impacted by the choice of visual encoder. In this paper, we integrate the DINOv2 foundation visual encoder with Diffusion Policy by designing a spatially-aware projection head, that allows the policy to shape its visual representation while benefiting from DINOv2’s robust embeddings. We evaluate this in drastic out-of-distribution conditions. As success rate can be uninformative in these conditions, where failure rates are high, we present three evaluation criteria for goal-driven policies that remain informative despite task failure. Our result shows that our approach outperforms the baseline under color alterations and camera displacements. We observe promising emergent task-relevant feature tracking using the DINOv2 visual encoder for policy learning.

title: Single-Machine Equivalent Modelling of Wind Farms Based on Data-Driven Multiplier Parameter Correction
authors: Weihan Hao, Jinchuan Guo, Cheng Su, Jianwu Wang, Yiping Lu, Zehaon Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: The rapid development of new energy power systems has raised higher demands for the accuracy and efficiency of wind farm equivalent modeling. To address the insufficient impedance parameter adaptation capability of the traditional single-machine multiplication model, this paper proposes a single-machine equivalent modeling method for wind farms based on data-driven multiplier parameter correction. By constructing a Backpropagation Neural Network (BP), a nonlinear mapping relationship is established between the number of units, operating conditions, and impedance parameters, enabling adaptive parameter adjustment. Additionally, a multi-machine equivalent model is built by clustering based on output distribution characteristics. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to traditional methods, the proposed approach significantly reduces active and reactive power errors under various operating conditions, effectively improves dynamic response accuracy while maintaining modeling efficiency, and provides a novel solution for efficient modeling of new energy power stations.

title: Integrating Automatic Force Assistance Configuration with Mixed Reality for Active Exoskeletons
authors: Olmo A. Moreno Franco, Gabriele Giurin, Yonas T. Tefera, Christian Di Natali, Luigi Monica, Darwin G. Caldwell, Jesus Ortiz
publish: 2026 IEEE/SICE International Symposium on System Integration (SII)
abstract: Work-related musculoskeletal disorders are highly prevalent in physically demanding industries due to manual material handling tasks such as lifting, hauling, and carrying heavy loads. Occupational exoskeleton technology has emerged to help mitigate these injuries. Exoskeletons are wearable devices that replicate the structure of the human body to enable mechanical interaction between the user and the system. Active exoskeletons use powered actuators and sensors to provide versatile and adaptive assistance for demanding tasks. However, a gap remains in user interaction and intuitive control for these systems. Human-computer interaction technologies, including mixed, virtual and augmented reality, offer novel solutions to enhance user interaction and enable intuitive, customisable control strategies for active exoskeletons. This study integrates mixed-reality technologies with the XoTrunk active occupational exoskeleton to enable parameter tuning and system calibration through immersive interfaces. Two alternative mixed-reality interfaces were developed for this purpose: one that relies on manual user input and the other that incorporates computer vision for automatic adjustment. Experiments involving 15 participants were conducted to evaluate interfaces by performing setup and operational activities while wearing the XoTrunk exoskeleton. The results showed that the automatic interface achieved a higher System Usability Scale score (84.83/100) compared to the manual interface (78.5/100), indicating improved user acceptance and intuitiveness.

title: Accurate PQ-ωV Admittance Model for Parallel VSC Systems
authors: Ziwen Zhao, Ronghui An, Zhiheng Huang, Boyang Shen, Hongwei Zhou, Jinjun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: This paper proposes an accurate PQ-ωV admittance model for parallel voltage-source converters with grid connection, comprehensively covering the dynamics of the power control, voltage-current dual-loop control, and all circuit components. Based on a unified synchronous reference frame of the system, the proposed model provides a tool to precisely depict the system stability and the oscillation characteristics of active/reactive power, frequency and voltage amplitude. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed modeling approach.

title: VAE-Based Synthetic EMG Generation with Mix-Consistency Loss for Recognizing Unseen Motion Combinations
authors: Itsuki Yazawa, Akira Furui
publish: 2026 IEEE/SICE International Symposium on System Integration (SII)
abstract: Electromyogram (EMG)-based motion classification using machine learning has been widely employed in applications such as prosthesis control. While previous studies have explored generating synthetic patterns of combined motions to reduce training data requirements, these methods assume that combined motions can be represented as linear combinations of basic motions. However, this assumption often fails due to complex neuromuscular phenomena such as muscle co-contraction, resulting in low-fidelity synthetic signals and degraded classification performance. To address this limitation, we propose a novel method that learns to synthesize combined motion patterns in a structured latent space. Specifically, we employ a variational autoencoder (VAE) to encode EMG signals into a low-dimensional representation and introduce a mix-consistency loss that structures the latent space such that combined motions are embedded between their constituent basic motions. Synthetic patterns are then generated within this structured latent space and used to train classifiers for recognizing unseen combined motions. We validated our approach through upper-limb motion classification experiments with eight healthy participants. The results demonstrate that our method outperforms input-space synthesis approaches, achieving approximately 30% improvement in accuracy.

title: Analysis and Design of a Novel 13.56 MHz Push-Pull Class E Inverter
authors: Jingbo Cui, Yueshi Guan, Yi Cheng, Yijie Wang, Dianguo Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: The radio frequency (RF) power amplifier constitutes an indispensable component in numerous academic, medical, and industrial applications. For these applications, the required power level in certain scenarios is sufficiently high that a single power amplification circuit cannot deliver adequate power. To address this issue, power combining networks are typically employed to synthesize the output power from multiple channels in various configurations, thereby mitigating impedance mismatches among power amplifiers. However, any power combining network inevitably introduces additional losses and increases the overall system volume. To facilitate more efficient power scaling, this study proposes a push-pull Class E topology from a structural perspective. Considering the power limitations of a single channel and the need for experimental adjustability, a matching network is incorporated for performance enhancement. Finally, a 13.56 MHz 500W prototype was constructed for experimental validation, achieving a peak efficiency of 87%.

title: HEART: Hybrid Energy-Aware Resilient Trust Evaluation Model for Healthcare-IoT
authors: Pramit Kumar Samant, Vinay Pathak, Waqar Ahmad
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Embedded Design (ISED)
abstract: In energy-constrained Healthcare IoT (HIoT) environments, maintaining the trustworthiness of sensor devices is vital for patient safety and system reliability. This paper introduces HEART, a Hybrid Energy-Aware Resilient Trust Evaluation model that consolidates four complementary trust dimensions—behavioural, energy, contextual, and historical—into a unified trust score. Unlike traditional centralized or static models, HEART employs dynamic weighting of trust components in response to real-time clinical and network contexts and executes trust computations in a fully distributed manner, thereby eliminating single points of failure and reducing latency. We conducted extensive MATLAB simulations on a 500-device HIoT network subjected to realistic Sybil, collusion, energy-drain, and false-data-injection attacks. Our results demonstrate an overall detection accuracy of 98.6% when only 10% of devices are malicious, gracefully degrading to 92.4% even at 50% malicious density. Attack-specific detection rates remain high at 98.1% for Sybil attacks, 95.2% for collusion, 97.4% for false data injection, and 96.8% for energy-drain attacks. False negative rates are impressively low, at 1.4% under light attack conditions and below 7.6% at maximum adversarial density. In terms of energy efficiency, HEART reduces per-device energy consumption by approximately 26%, requiring only 1.18 J per evaluation compared to 1.60 J for static model and 1.82 J for blockchain-based approach. Moreover, trust convergence time is accelerated by over 40%, stabilizing in just 83 s under low attack scenarios versus 140 s and 120 s for the static [12] and blockchain [19] baselines respectively. Trust convergence time increased marginally from 83 s to 118 s, indicating linear scalability.

title: Universal DC-DC Topology Deduction Mechanism Based on Graph-Theoretic Weighting and Four-Dimensional Electrical Characteristics
authors: Xinyue Chen, Liping Mo, Weijing Yang, Guipeng Chen, Xinlin Qing
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: Conventional topology deduction for non-resonant DC-DC converters faces dual challenges: low efficiency in manual derivation and non-systematic electrical conditions in computer-aided approaches. To further enhance the universality of electrical conditions, this paper establishes systematic component-to-electrical mapping via a four-dimensional electrical attribute framework (average/instantaneous voltage/current), deri ving universal loop/cut-set constraints (USP/ISP). Concurrently, this paper employs graph theory modeling to transform electrical conditions into graph constraints and adopts a Minimum-Unknown-Constraint-First Incremental Weighted Topology Deduction Algorithm based on dynamic programming for topology verification. These electrical conditions are applicable to DC-DC converters with numerous components. Using the S1-D3-L1 -C2 type DC-DC converter as an example, 18 topologies were deduced through algorithm execution, verifying the practicality and accuracy of the proposed electrical conditions.

title: Urban Sound Classification: A Lightweight CNN Approach Based on Mel-Spectrograms
authors: Pengshun Che, Jiaan Liu, Jiacheng Lu
publish: 2025 6th International Symposium on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Communications (ISCEIC)
abstract: Urban sound classification plays a crucial role in smart city applications, enabling noise monitoring, emergency detection, and environmental analysis. This paper proposes a lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model tailored for classifying urban sounds using Mel-spectrograms derived from a subset of the UrbanSound8K dataset. The model emphasizes efficient signal preprocessing via Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) and Mel-scale filtering to capture salient frequency-time features, achieving a test accuracy of 86.53% on a 1000-sample subset while utilizing only 181k parameters. Inspired by self-supervised multisensory features from ICCV 2019, our approach integrates data augmentation and shallow convolutional layers to balance performance and computational efficiency. Extensive experiments demonstrate superior results over baselines like ResNet-18 and MFCC+SVM, with ablation studies validating the contributions of preprocessing and augmentation. The lightweight design ensures rapid training (12.13 minutes) and inference (0.237 seconds), making it suitable for edge devices. This work advances accessible urban acoustics analysis, paving the way for real-time deployments in resource-constrained environments.

title: The Impact of Temperature Sensors in IoT on Fermentation in Eco-Enzymes
authors: Princen Putra Kurniawan, Jason Yoswara, Mochammad Haldi Widianto
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Emerging Trends in Information Systems and Informatics (ICETISI)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has presented significant opportunities in recent years. Many fermentation processes have been monitored and controlled with IoT to improve them, for example, eco-enzyme production. Fermenting organic waste with eco-enzymes with consistent results has been proven to provide significant benefits to the economy and the environment. Temperature is a key parameter in fermentation. Uncontrolled temperature can cause unwanted microbial activity and even death, ultimately reducing the quality of eco-enzymes. This study examine how IoT-based monitoring can help us control the temperature during the eco-enzyme fermentation process. By using temperature and humidity sensors connected to an Arduino microcontroller and the Blynk platform, it helps enable real-time monitoring and helps maintain stable conditions throughout fermentation. The results show that this approach of implementing IoT into the eco-enzyme not only help improve efficiency and consistency of eco-enzyme production but also demonstrates the potential IoT solutions for small-scale or household applications in sustainable organic waste management. In short the data collected shows that with the Eco-Enzyme Tracker it helps monitor the fermentation process.

title: Hardware-Decoupled High-Frequency Triple Active Bridge (TAB) Converter
authors: Bin Zhang, Lining Zhao, Shihao Zhang, Wei Zheng, Yanjun Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: To address the complexity of conventional high-frequency triple active bridge (TAB) converter control schemes, this paper proposes a hardware-decoupled high-frequency TAB architecture. The power transfer characteristics under hardware decoupling are thoroughly analyzed, based on which the TAB converter is equivalently transformed into a cascaded configuration of two dual active bridge (DAB) converters. Six distinct operating modes of the TAB converter are identified and classified. For the DAB converter, an extended phase shift (EPS) control strategy optimized for current stress is developed for both forward and reverse power flow, where the intra-bridge phase shift angle is allocated on the full-bridge side connected to the inductor. The resulting EPS strategy is adapted to the hardware-decoupled high-frequency TAB converter. Experimental results at a switching frequency of 100 kHz under varying power levels verify the feasibility of the proposed hardware-decoupled TAB converter across all six operating modes.

title: Development and Testing of Avalanche Transistors and Sub-nanosecond Pulses
authors: Kaijun Wen, Lin Liang, Tianyi Wang, Jiayi Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: In response to the growing application of ultra-wideband (UWB) technology in external environment positioning and guidance, this work investigates the fundamental technology of the avalanche bipolar junction transistor (ABJT), a key component of UWB pulse systems. An ABJT device model is established, and its static and dynamic characteristics are systematically simulated. On the fabrication side, ABJT device samples with a breakdown voltage of 300 V are successfully developed. In application testing, a Marx circuit designed using ABJTs generates sub-nanosecond pulses with a 200 ps rising edge and a peak amplitude of 1200 V. The results provide both an experimental foundation and enabling technologies for the design, fabrication, and application of ABJT devices.

title: An Optimized Switch Fault Diagnosis Strategy for Cascaded H-Bridge Based STATCOM
authors: Hai Huang, Liu Yang, Yincong Chen, Haoran Lu, Hanyu Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: The cascaded H-bridge (CHB) converter is widely used in the static synchronous compensators (STACOM) due to its high modularity, strong fault tolerance, and other advantages. However, the CHB contains a large number of power switches, which significantly increases the probability of faults. Therefore, a simple and efficient fault diagnosis (FD) strategy is essential. In this paper, an optimized FD strategy considering the impact of voltage balancing control is proposed. Additionally, system redundancy is utilized for fault tolerant (FT) strategy, and this is combined with the location of the faulty switch. Finally, the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by Matlab/Simulink simulation. The time interval from the occurrence of a fault to the restoration of system health is less than two fundamental cycles.

title: Diffusion-based Multi-agent with Reinforcement Learning for Multimodal-based Recommendation
authors: Yijun Hu, Rui Tang, Hao Liu, Xian Mo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Big Data
abstract: Multimodal-based recommendation integrates visual, textual, and acoustic modalities of items to comprehensively capture user preferences, thereby playing a crucial role in modern multimedia online platforms. In this paper, we propose a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</u>iffusion-based Multi-agent with <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">R</u>einforcement Learning for <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M</u>ultimodal-based <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rec</u>ommendation (DRMRec). Specifically, our DRMRec first leverages a hierarchical <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</u>iffusion-based <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M</u>ulti-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</u>gent (DMA) to reconstruct the user-item interaction graph. Subsequently, these reconstructed graphs are fused with multimodal information to form contrastive views. During the reconstruction, each agent is injected with multimodal information through a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">C</u>ross-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M</u>odal <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</u>ligner (CMA), thereby bringing cross-modal information closer to interaction embeddings and facilitating alignment across modalities. Then, we introduce a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M</u>etric-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</u>ware <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</u>iffusion <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">R</u>einforcer (MADR), a reinforcement learning framework that leverages validation-set recommendation metrics as reward signals to enable dynamic and individual fine-tuning of each agent, thereby actively aligning model optimization with recommendation tasks. Next, we apply cross-modal graph contrastive learning to contrastive views, alleviating data sparsity while further enhancing cross-modal alignment. Extensive experiments on three real-world multimedia platform datasets demonstrate that DRMRec consistently outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in multimodal-based recommendation. It is noteworthy that the performance improvements across all three metrics on both the TikTok and Sports datasets exceed 10%.

title: Anchor-guided Discrete Multi-view Clustering
authors: Ran Jing, Quanxue Gao, Yu Duan, Cheng Deng, Ming Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: Multi-view clustering based on anchor graphs has attracted significant attention due to its ability to substantially reduce computational complexity, enabling the efficient processing of large-scale multimedia data. However, most existing anchor graph-based clustering methods fail to fully exploit the intrinsic properties of anchor graphs when applying regression techniques. Moreover, some approaches focus solely on sample labels while overlooking the crucial role of anchor labels in clustering. To address these limitations, we leverage the probabilistic information of the anchor graph by employing probabilistic projection to map the anchor graph into the label space, thereby obtaining anchor labels. By clustering both anchors and samples simultaneously, the anchor graph serves as a guide to induce anchor labels, which are then used to generate sample labels, facilitating anchor-guided sample clustering. Furthermore, we propose a novel regularization paradigm based on the matrix nuclear norm, ensuring that the obtained results remain discrete and that the sample distribution across clusters is balanced. Additionally, we introduce a new matrix nuclear norm optimization method based on the first-order Taylor expansion. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of our proposed method, achieving superior performance compared to state-of-the-art approaches. Our code is available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/harunakai/ADMC</uri>

title: Sounding Depressed? Personalized Deep Learning Model for Depression Detection from Speech and Text
authors: Haibo Zhang, Zhenyu Liu, Jiaqian Yuan, Gang Li, Zhijie Ding, Bin Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: Automatic depression detection technology based on speech and text data is one of the current research hotspots. However, numerous current models may inadequately incorporate the individual characteristics important for improving detection precision. This leads to misjudgment when the model deals with a depressed patient whose behavior significantly differs from the majority of patients. Thus, the goal of this research is to extract individual characteristics from speech and text data among individuals and develop an efficient and stable personalized model for depression detection. We propose a personalized multimodal depression detection model (PMDDM). The proposed model generates personalized embeddings for each individual by utilizing both speech and text features, while learning depressive representations and integrating them with personalized embeddings for joint representations. Lastly, the model receives the joint representations to predict the individual's depression status. We evaluated the proposed model using two datasets related to depression detection, MODMA and MIDD. Compared to the best baseline methods, our method improved the recognition accuracy by 5.88% and 3.84% on the MODMA and MIDD datasets, respectively. The F1 scores increased by 4.55% and 3.45%, respectively. In the cross-dataset generalizability experiments, our method still outperformed the best baseline methods in F1 score and accuracy. Results suggest that the effective integration of personalized information can significantly improve the accuracy and generalizability of depression detection models. Our research provides novel insights into personalized depression detection.

title: Decouple, Reorganize, and Fuse: A Multimodal Framework for Cancer Survival Prediction
authors: Huayi Wang, Haochao Ying, Yuyang Xu, Qibo Qiu, Cheng Zhang, Danny Z. Chen, Ying Sun, Jian Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: Cancer survival analysis commonly integrates information across diverse medical modalities to make survival-time predictions. Existing methods primarily focus on extracting different decoupled features of modalities and performing fusion operations such as concatenation, attention, and Mixture-of-Experts (MoE)-based fusion. However, these methods still face two key challenges: i) fixed fusion schemes (concatenation and attention) can lead to model over-reliance on predefined feature combinations, limiting the dynamic fusion of decoupled features; ii) in MoE-based fusion methods, each expert network handles separate decoupled features, which limits information interaction among the decoupled features. To address these challenges, we propose a novel Decoupling-Reorganization-Fusion framework (DeReF), which devises a random feature reorganization strategy between modalities decoupling and dynamic MoE fusion modules. Its advantages are: i) it increases the diversity of feature combinations and granularity, enhancing the generalization ability of the subsequent expert networks; ii) it overcomes the problem of information closure and helps expert networks better capture information among decoupled features. Additionally, we incorporate a regional cross-attention network within the modality decoupling module to improve the representation quality of decoupled features. Extensive experimental results on our in-house Liver Cancer (LC) and three widely used public datasets from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) confirm the effectiveness of our proposed method. Codes are available at https://github.com/ZJUMAI/DeReF.

title: SegTrans: Transferable Adversarial Examples for Segmentation Models
authors: Yufei Song, Ziqi Zhou, Qi Lu, Hangtao Zhang, Yifan Hu, Lulu Xue, Shengshan Hu, Minghui Li, Leo Yu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: Segmentation models exhibit significant vulnerability to adversarial examples in white-box settings, but existing adversarial attack methods often show poor transferability across different segmentation models. While some researchers have explored transfer-based adversarial attack (i.e., transfer attack) methods for segmentation models, the complex contextual dependencies within these models and the feature distribution gaps between surrogate and target models result in unsatisfactory transfer success rates. To address these issues, we propose SegTrans, a novel transfer attack framework that divides the input sample into multiple local regions and remaps their se mantic information to generate diverse enhanced samples. These enhanced samples replace the original ones for perturbation optimization, thereby improving the transferability of adversarial examples across different segmentation models. Unlike existing methods, SegTrans only retains local semantic information from the original input, rather than using global semantic information to optimize perturbations. Extensive experiments on two bench mark datasets, PASCAL VOC and Cityscapes, four different segmentation models, and three backbone networks show that SegTrans significantly improves adversarial transfer success rates without introducing additional computational overhead. Compared to the current state-of-the-art methods, SegTrans achieves an average increase of 8.55% in transfer attack success rate and improves computational efficiency by more than 100%. The code is available at https://github.com/Yufei-17/SegTrans.

title: Compositional Text-to-Image Synthesis with Training-Free Layout-Guided Diffusion
authors: Xiaoling Gu, Lingwei Luo, Shengqi Wu, Zizhao Wu, Zhenzhong Kuang, Zhou Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: Recent text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models have made significant strides in generating high-quality images from diverse textual prompts. Despite this progress, these models often face challenges in accurately understanding and synthesizing complex prompts, primarily due to their limited compositional capabilities. In this study, we propose a novel approach for compositional T2I synthesis using layout-guided diffusion models, which do not require additional training. Specifically, we leverage the chain-of-code prompting technique of large language models to interpret textual prompts and generate object layouts with spatial coherence. To enhance the alignment between generated images and textual descriptions, we introduce two innovative layoutguided loss functions: Patch-oriented Cross-Attention (PCA) loss and Region-oriented Cross-Attention (RCA) loss. The PCA loss emphasizes high activation values for image patches that attend to all tokens in the prompt across the layout. The RCA loss enhances the average attention within the layout, thereby increasing the accuracy of generating objects and their associated attributes within specified regions. These proposed loss functions reassign cross-attention in diffusion models during the denoising process. Our comprehensive experiments consistently demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving semantic alignment between generated images and a diverse range of textual prompts, while ensuring high usability as a ready-to-use plugin. Our code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/gxl-groups/Compositional-T2I</uri>.

title: Reasoning Techniques Meet GraphRAG: Advancing LLM for Wireless Network Cyber Defense
authors: Shuang Tian, Tao Zhang, Ruichen Zhang, Xiangyun Tang, Zhi Liu, Jiawen Kang, Jiqiang Liu, Dusit Niyato, Dong In Kim
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: Recently, cyberattacks have quickly evolved and transformed from isolated incidents into multiple layers, multi-stage attack chains, posing unprecedented challenges to cybersecurity defenses. Large Language Models (LLMs), with their powerful comprehension and generation capabilities, are emerging as a crucial technological foundation for next-generation intelligent defense systems. However, when confronting complex cyber threats, the LLMs relying solely on understanding and generation remain inadequate. Enhancing their reasoning and decision-making capabilities has thus become a key direction in current cybersecurity research. Focusing on this direction, this paper first outlines evolving demands of cybersecurity and comprehensively reviews existing reasoning techniques. We then integrate GraphRAG into reasoning techniques, proposing an LLM reasoning framework tailored for cybersecurity scenarios. The framework provides models with accurate context and guides their decisions through reasoning techniques. This enhances their reasoning capabilities when confronting complex cybersecurity problems. This enables them to identify threats, reconstruct attack chains, and generate defense strategies, particularly against multi-layered, multi-stage attacks. Subsequently, we validate the effectiveness of our proposed framework through a case study focused on Low Altitude Economy Networks (LAENets) communication. Finally, we summarize potential future research directions in this field.

title: A Wearable Hand Tremor-Suppressing Glove Using PVC Gel-Based Actuators and Force Sensors
authors: Chen Liu, Yan Wang, Ketao Zhang
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Hand tremor significantly impairs daily activities, affecting the quality of life for millions worldwide. Compared to traditional invasive treatments, noninvasive wearable devices offer a promising, more convenient, and safer alternative but often struggle to balance tremor suppression efficacy, wearability, and comfort. This study presents a novel wearable hand tremor-suppressing orthosis glove integrating semi-active and active control schemes using flexible polyvinyl chloride gel-based actuators and sensors. The glove integrates first, self-sensing semi-active absorbers to detect and suppress wrist and finger tremors, second, active fingertip tremor absorbers to counteract fingertip tremor forces, and third, two types of flexible sensors (resistive strain sensors and capacitive force sensors) to ensure accurate detection whether the hand is trembling in the air or in contact with a surface. Simulations and experiments validate the glove’s ability to suppress tremors across a wide frequency range (3–12 Hz), achieving a suppression ratio of up to 81.7% at the fingertips. Compared to state-of-the-art solutions, the glove achieves a superior suppression-per-power metric of 163.4%/W, while maintaining low weight (155 g) and flexibility, enhancing comfort and adaptability. This work advances wearable tremor suppression by integrating semi-active and active schemes, offering a noninvasive and effective solution for hand tremors.

title: Hybrid Discretized Luenberger Observer for Sensorless IPMSM Drives Under Low Sampling-to-Fundamental Frequency Ratio
authors: Boyu Zhang, Zheng Wang, Minrui Gu, Yinzhen Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: In this article, a Luenberger observer discretized by a hybrid method for interior permanent magnet synchronous machine (IPMSM) sensorless drives is proposed. It owns high discretization accuracy and is easy to implement in digital control systems, enabling it to be applied to low sampling-to-fundamental frequency ratio (SFR) high speed motor drives. First, the conventional discretization methods are investigated. Then, the hybrid method combining forward Euler (FE) method and fourth-order Runge-Kutta (RK-4) method is presented. All the methods are evaluated from two aspects: discretization error and computational cost. After that, the design of the proposed Luenberger observer is introduced. Finally, simulation results are given to validate the proposed scheme.

title: Accurate Time-Domain Model for Flying Capacitor Based Three-Level LLC Resonant Converters
authors: Shuo Zhang, Ziang Li, Qi Zhang, Junhong Yu, Jinjun Liu, Yuqi Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: X7R-type ceramic capacitors are widely used as flying capacitors in three-level LLC resonant converters (FC- TL LLC) due to their high permittivity and compact size. However, critical effects including the flying capacitance derating under DC bias condition, voltage fluctuations, and resonant frequency deviation are often ignored. This paper proposes an accurate time-domain model for FC-TL LLC based on fundamental operational stages iteration, which incorporates these often-neglected effects along with common parasitic components. Analytical expressions are available to enable fast and precise performance evaluation. Simulation results validate the model’s accuracy and improved voltage gain prediction over the conventional methods.

title: Wide Range Series Resonant Converter with Double-Mode Operation Control Strategy
authors: Pengyu Jia, Yimei Xing, Mingwang Yang, Mei Liang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: The dual active bridge series resonant converter (DAB-SRC) often requires extremely high switching frequency to maintain soft switching under conditions of voltage gain deviation from unit gain and light load, which limits its application in a wide voltage range. To address this issue, this paper proposes a topology optimization method with an additional inductor. By controlling the phase relationship (in-phase/anti-phase) of the driving pulses, it achieves the switching between full-bridge and half-bridge modes, changing the characteristic impedance and resonant frequency of the converter, effectively reducing the switching frequency under light load and widening the voltage range. This paper firstly establishes time-domain analytical models for both full-bridge and half-bridge operating modes using a single half-bridge as the basic circuit unit, solves the converter model with switching frequency and single phase-shift as control variables, and plots the soft switching region boundaries considering the influence of deadtime. On this basis, a hybrid control strategy is proposed —the full-bridge mode employs constant -frequency phase-shift control based on the linear relationship between frequency and gain, while the half-bridge mode adopts variable-frequency phase-shift control based on the linear relationship between frequency and load, so as to achieve soft switching over the entire voltage range. Finally, validation is carried out using a 1.2 kW experimental prototype.

title: Estimation of Flux Saturation Model for SynRMs Using Physics-Informed Neural Networks at Standstill
authors: Cheng Ye, Yankai Jia, Yusheng Song, Changxing Guo, Chuanwen Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: This paper presents a high-precision flux linkage identification method for synchronous reluctance motors (SynRMs) using physics-informed neural networks (PINNs). Traditional approaches like polynomial fitting or finite element analysis (FEA) often face limitations in either accuracy or computational efficiency. The proposed PINN framework integrates physical knowledge, including partial differential equations, initial conditions, and reciprocity constraints, directly into the neural network training process. This combination of data-driven learning with physics-based constraints improves modeling accuracy and robustness. Additionally, a novel data acquisition method based on voltage injection experiments which does not require rotor locking or position sensors is developed to facilitate practical and comprehensive data collection. Extensive simulations conducted on a Siemens 0.55 kW industrial SynRM verify that the PINN method substantially outperforms conventional artificial neural networks (ANNs) in terms of modeling accuracy, physical consistency, robustness to data quality and quantity variations, and generalization capability. The results demonstrate that the PINN framework not only enhances the fidelity and reliability of flux linkage identification but also simplifies experimental procedures, thereby offering a promising and scalable solution for intelligent modeling and control of SynRMs and similar nonlinear electromagnetic systems.

title: Energy Management Optimization for Photovoltaic Hydrogen Production System
authors: Lei Guo, Boyang Zhao, Meijian Wang, Yuan Gao, Ning Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: This paper investigates the energy optimization control of photovoltaic (PV) hydrogen production systems. First, a multi-time-scale dynamic model is constructed, covering the internal characteristics of the electrolyzer, and systematically reveals the influence mechanisms of factors such as fluctuations in PV power output on electrolysis efficiency and system stability. Second, an energy management strategy based on deep reinforcement learning is proposed. In terms of energy dispatch strategy, a multi-objective optimization model is developed, targeting hydrogen production efficiency and reliability, to achieve intelligent optimization of multi-source dynamic dispatch. Finally, test results validate the effectiveness of the proposed solution.

title: GS-MATSC: Group Symmetric Multi-Agent Traffic Signal Control with Attention and Mirror Loss
authors: Dawei Shi, Haoqi Xu, Yulu Li, Yitong Bai
publish: 2025 6th International Symposium on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Communications (ISCEIC)
abstract: This paper introduces GS-MATSC, a novel Multi- Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) framework designed to address the curse of dimensionality in large-scale traffic signal control. Built upon Multi-Agent PPO (MAPPO), the model incorporates group symmetry principles to enhance generalization and training efficiency. Specifically, a multi-head attention-based policy network ensures permutation equivariance among agents, while a mirror auxiliary loss enforces rotational symmetry in road network structures. Experiments conducted in SUMO simulations with 12 and 18 traffic light agents demonstrate that GS-MATSC significantly improves sample efficiency, policy stability, and traffic metrics—such as reducing delay time and queue length—compared to baseline methods. The framework offers a scalable and robust solution for coordinated traffic signal control in complex urban networks.

title: A Multi-Layered Security Framework for NIfTI Images Using CNN Feature Extraction, Arnold Scrambling and DWT Watermarking
authors: Aradhana Soni, Amit Kumar Dewangan, Ankit Kumar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Embedded Design (ISED)
abstract: The wide accumulation of digitized medical images, especially in 3D formats such as NIfTI, has become a significant threat to data integrity, privacy and secure sharing. This paper proposes a new multi-layer security scheme for NIfTI medical images that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), ARNOLD transformation to spatially scramble an image, and discrete wavelet transformation (DWT) for watermark embedding. Watermarks are placed in nondiagnostic areas only to ensure diagnostic quality studies. Experiments on Brats and ADNI demonstrate the impressive performance: PSNR $(40.87 \mathrm{~dB})$, SSIM (0.956), NC (0.97), BER (0.018) and ROI Preservation Score (0.98). The developed framework exhibits high robustness, real-time efficiency and adaptivity for secure reversible protection of the volumetric medical data and outperforms the current approaches in fidelity and resilience as well.

title: Research on Construction and Dynamic Evolution of Knowledge Graph for University History Archive Resources Based on Multimodal Data
authors: Yougan Luo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mechanical Automation and Electronic Information Engineering (MAEIE)
abstract: Addressing the issues of weak semantic associations in multimodal data (text, images), the difficulty in capturing the evolutionary context of long-span historical events, and the uneven quality of old archives in current university history archive management, this paper proposes a Multimodal Knowledge Graph with Dynamic Evolution (MMKG-DE) model based on visual semantic enhancement and time-sensitivity perception. At the methodological level, distinct from standard fusion methods that rely on simple zero-filling, the model designs a Visual Hallucination Completion Mechanism to reconstruct the semantic manifold of incomplete data rather than introducing feature distortion. Secondly, to overcome the catastrophic forgetting in snapshot-based RNN models caused by sparse intervals, a Time-Sensitivity Aware Translation function is constructed to precisely model non-stationary evolutionary laws. Comparative experiments on a self-constructed university history dataset (SH-Data) and public benchmark datasets (WN9-IMG, FB15K-237-IMG) demonstrate that MMKG-DE significantly outperforms existing advanced models such as RE-NET and MKG-GNN in core metrics like entity alignment (MRR=0.658) and dynamic link prediction (Hits@10=0.745), confirming the robustness and effectiveness of this method in complex archival scenarios.

title: Applying Vision-Language Models for Intelligent Multimodal Surveillance and Crime Detection
authors: Nishchay Gupta, Kunal, Madhav Sachar, Rupali Pandey, Vishal Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE DELCON - International Conference on Recent Smart Technologies in Engineering for Sustainable Development
abstract: With growing security concerns in the modern world, a requirement of a modern surveillance solution is generated. The current state of technology offers solutions in the form of custom built, fine-tuned neural networks to automate the process of detecting abnormal behaviour. These systems often rely on pretrained neural networks like ResNet, YOLOv5, etc. The research paper aims to explore new technology in the domain of smart surveillance to further the cause of a secure future for humanity as a whole. The proposed paper proposes the utilisation of pretrained Multi-Modal Models which can take Audio and Visual cues to identify Abnormal behaviour and further increase the pinpoint accuracy of the model. Other than the obvious advantage, these models like Gemini Vision offer Multimodal analysis of the input data therefore helping to further pinpoint the occurrence of abnormal behaviour in the input footage. The implemented system achieved an overall accuracy of 75%, with a precision of 93.3%, recall of 66.7%, and F1-score of 77.8% for crime detection, indicating strong performance in identifying actual criminal activities. By utilising the recent advancements in the field of deep learning the smart surveillance system offers an opportunity for the nation to develop into a more secure, peaceful state.

title: A Localization Strategy for Low-cost UAVs Sewers Inspection
authors: Paolo Maisto, Vincenzo Scognamiglio, Mario Selvaggio, Vincenzo Lippiello
publish: 2026 IEEE/SICE International Symposium on System Integration (SII)
abstract: Inspecting sewers represents a significant challenge as these environments pose considerable safety risks to human operators. In this view, drones capable of autonomous flight can be used to perform inspection tasks reducing human exposure. However, sewer environments are typically confined, featureless, and poorly lit, hence, standard algorithms for the localization in GNSS-denied environments, such as Visual-Inertial Odometry (VIO), often fail. In addition, drone localization is further complicated by rotor-induced turbulence, and vibrations, that affect sensor measurements. This paper presents a low-cost multisensor-based method for robust pose reconstruction of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to enable reliable navigation in visually degraded, GPS-denied environments. The proposed framework leverages environmental geometry, specifically obstacle and wall distances, to estimate relative motion and correct drift via a speed control strategy that maximizes the distance from any obstacle. The approach is validated through both simulation and real-world experiments, demonstrating its effectiveness in representative scenarios.

title: An Overall Loss Modeling Considering Current Ripple for Hybrid 3L-ANPC Converters
authors: Xiaoxuan Yao, Chenglong Dong, Yonghao Li, Xin Xiang, Wuhua Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: Accurate system-level loss prediction is essential for designing efficient power electronic converters. This work develops an overall loss model for a hybrid three-level active neutral-point-clamped (3L-ANPC) converter that explicitly incorporates the converter-side inductor current ripple. First, an analytical expression is derived for the peak-to-peak ripple as a function of switching frequency and modulation, while capturing the inductance nonlinearity of the LCL filter (mainly converter-side inductor). The resulting ripple is then embedded in semiconductor loss calculations—covering both conduction loss and the distinct turn-on/turn-off switching energies—and in the inductor core loss via Steinmetz-type formulations that map ripple current to flux-density swing. By sweeping switching frequency, the model captures the trade-off between device switching loss and magnetic core loss and identifies the frequency that maximizes efficiency. Experimental results on a 215kW, 1330Vdc, 690Vac prototype validate the analysis. The proposed framework therefore provides a practical basis for selecting switching frequency in hybrid 3L-ANPC systems with LCL filters.

title: A Disturbance-Triggered Dual-Agent Reinforcement Learning Frequency Compensation Strategy with Lyapunov-Guided Stability for LLC Resonant Converters
authors: Xiaokun Bao, Xueqi Liu, Xin Zhang, Zhengfang Zhang, Yelai Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid control strategy for LLC resonant converters that enhances transient performance while preserving the simplicity of conventional PI regulation. A reinforcement learning-based frequency compensator is introduced, which is selectively triggered during input voltage disturbances. Instead of replacing the base controller, the proposed method injects a one-time frequency correction to quickly suppress voltage deviations. A dual-agent architecture is adopted to handle rising and falling disturbances independently, and a Lyapunov-guided reward function is used to ensure stable convergence during compensation. Experimental results from step-up and step-down tests verify that the proposed method significantly improves voltage recovery speed and reduces overshoot, making it a lightweight yet effective solution for dynamic stabilization in LLC converters.

title: An Improved Passivity-Based Control Method for Three-Phase ANPC Inverters under Weak Grid
authors: Chenglong Dong, Xiaoxuan Yao, Yuxuan Lin, Ke Cheng, Xin Xiang, Wuhua Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: Passivity-based control (PBC) methods have been extensively studied and widely applied to grid-connected inverters to achieve improved control performance. This paper focuses on a three-phase active neutral point clamped (ANPC) inverter. First, the Euler-Lagrange model of the inverter is established, and the passivity of the system is verified. Based on damping injection, the passivity-based controller is designed. The control mechanism and steady-state error characteristics are analyzed in detail, and an automatic parameter tuning method is proposed. An impedance model of the passive controller is further developed to analyze system stability under weak grid conditions. Compared to conventional PI control, the passive controller exhibits superior robustness. Finally, to enhance the controller’s robustness against grid impedance variations, an impedance reshaping method based on inverter-side current feedback is introduced. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy in steady-state error suppression and robustness to grid impedance variations.

title: Adaptive Communication Protocols for Manager-Worker Small LLM Multi-Agent Systems in Resource-Constrained Environments
authors: Kumar Yashu, Vyshali J Gogi, Azarudheen S
publish: 2025 IEEE DELCON - International Conference on Recent Smart Technologies in Engineering for Sustainable Development
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) and edge computing paradigms has necessitated the deployment of intelligent multi-agent systems in resource-constrained environments, where traditional communication protocols fail to optimize bandwidth utilization and energy consumption. This paper presents a novel adaptive communication framework specifically designed for manager-worker small Large Language Models (LLMs) multi-agent systems operating under stringent computational, memory, and energy constraints. Our approach integrates three synergistic innovations: (1) a lightweight semantic filtering module employing knowledge-distilled small LLMs (DistilBERT 66M parameters, TinyBERT 4.4M parameters) for real-time extraction of task-relevant information with minimal computational overhead, (2) a dynamic hierarchical coordination scheme enabling runtime role reassignment based on evolving task complexity and resource availability, and (3) an adaptive topology control mechanism leveraging algebraic connectivity measures to optimize network robustness while minimizing communication overhead. Comprehensive simulation-based evaluation across five distinct IoT deployment scenarios demonstrates substantial improvements in communication efficiency, achieving an average token reduction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 7. 4 \%}$</tex> (range: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 4. 1 - 5 9. 4 \%}$</tex>) while maintaining task completion rates within 8.3 percentage points of baseline performance. The framework exhibits superior coordination quality improvements of 6.0 %, coupled with significant resource optimization including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 1. 2 \%}$</tex> CPU usage reduction and 50.4 % energy savings, validating its practical suitability for edge computing deployments in resource-critical applications.

title: Improving Robotic Imitation Learning with Predicted Facial Motion Using Transformers
authors: Yitong Li, Fumio Kanehiro
publish: 2026 IEEE/SICE International Symposium on System Integration (SII)
abstract: This study proposes a Transformer-based approach with cross attention for predicting human facial movements in face-related robotic control tasks and integrating these predictions into an imitation learning framework. A dataset of human facial videos was constructed, and landmarks were extracted using the MediaPipe framework. Three prediction methods were compared, and the cross-attention model achieved the best performance in both landmark localization accuracy and image quality. In imitation learning experiments, facial motion trajectories sampled from real human data trajectories were used, and the success rate increased from 42% to 60% and ultimately to 74% when predicted landmarks were incorporated. Additionally, varying the prediction horizon affected task completion time, with the 2-frame horizon achieving the fastest completion. These results demonstrate that incorporating predicted facial motion can significantly enhance robotic control performance in dynamic human-robot interaction scenarios.

title: Research on Transformer with Variable Magnetizing Inductance Applied to Dual Mode LLC-DAB Converter
authors: Zheng Lu, Zinan Lou, Peinan Rao, Shuai Zhou, Yan Zhang, Jinjun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: Bidirectional isolated DC-DC topologies, particularly LLC and DAB converters, have found widespread applications in DC microgrids, energy storage systems, and electric vehicles. Numerous studies have investigated improved topologies to combine their respective advantages. This paper presents an improved dual-transformer structure for a dual-mode LLC-DAB converter, achieving mode-dependent magnetizing inductance characteristics: low equivalent inductance in LLC mode for enhanced voltage regulation, and high equivalent inductance in DAB mode for reduced circulating current. This adaptive design meets varying excitation current requirements across operational scenarios, thereby improving system efficiency. Theoretical analysis and simulation results validate the proposed structure's operating principles.

title: An ISO/IEC 25010-Based Evaluation Methodology for Designing Digital Mock-Up Toward Nuclear Decommissioning
authors: Fumiaki Abe, Kuniaki Kawabata, Wataru Sato, Tomoki Sakaue
publish: 2026 IEEE/SICE International Symposium on System Integration (SII)
abstract: This paper describes an ISO/IEC 25010-based evaluation methodology for designing Digital Mock-Up (DMU) toward nuclear decommissioning. Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings, Inc. (TEPCO) is planning to develop a DMU to facilitate safe and reliable decommissioning operations using remote-control robots since the conditions inside the reactor buildings remain many unknown unknowns. To effectively implement the DMU, it is essential to carefully select available software technologies, install them, and adopt a software system integration framework to organize the DMU. Therefore, appropriate evaluations must be conducted. In this paper, we proposed a quantitative method for evaluating the functionality and systemization of the DMU based on a software quality requirements and evaluation model ISO/IEC 25010. Also, we reported a case study in which the proposed evaluation methodology was applied to a fundamental DMU developed based on a typical use case.

title: Research on Control and Modulation Strategy for Reusing Module Soft Open Point Topology
authors: Runyan Sha, Wu Chen, Haixi Zhao, Yutong Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: Flexible Multi-State Switch (Soft Open Point, SOP), leveraging power electronic devices, enables continuous power flow regulation and rapid operational state transitions under conditions of high-penetration distributed energy resources and diverse load types. This capability addresses limitations inherent in traditional mechanical switches. However, constrained by the voltage withstand capability and loss characteristics of power electronic devices, medium-voltage SOP implementations necessitate cascading multiple modules to match the required voltage level. This cascading approach results in issues such as a high redundant module configuration rate and suboptimal operating efficiency.The reusing module soft open point (RM-SOP) topology mitigates these drawbacks by reducing the number of cascaded modules through a module reuse strategy. Introducing a novel hybrid modulation strategy for the shared modules, combining square-wave modulation and sinusoidal pulse-width modulation (PWM). This proposed strategy aims to reduce switching losses during modulation and enhance overall system efficiency. Finally, simulation studies are presented to validate the feasibility and correctness of both the proposed control scheme and the modulation strategy.

title: Spam Email Classification using Bag-of-Words Features and Multilayer Perceptron Neural Networks
authors: Yessi Jusman, Rifki Asidqiyah, Maryza Intan Rahmawati
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Emerging Trends in Information Systems and Informatics (ICETISI)
abstract: Email has become one of the most widely adopted tools for both personal and professional communication, but its growing reliance has been accompanied by the prevalence of unsolicited messages, commonly referred to as spam. Spam clutters inboxes, reduces productivity, and poses security risks, making effective detection methods increasingly crucial. This study evaluated the performance of multi-layer perceptron (MLP) models trained with two optimization algorithms: One-Step Secant (OSS) and Scaled Conjugate Gradient (SCG). A bag-of-words dataset was utilized, and representative statistical features were analyzed to characterize distinctions between spam and non-spam categories. The MLP was trained using two hidden neuron configurations (5 and 10) to examine the influence of network complexity on performance. Experimental results revealed that SCG consistently outperformed OSS, achieving average accuracies of 92.9% (training), 91.3% (validation), and 92.6% (testing) with 10 hidden neurons. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis further confirmed the robustness of SCG, demonstrating better tradeoffs between true positive and false positive rates. These findings highlight SCG as a more reliable optimization approach for spam classification.

title: Capacitor Voltage Reconfiguration and Control Methods of Variable-Level ANPC Inverters
authors: Jupeng Pang, Chao Wang, Mingzhe Wu, Kui Wang, Zedong Zheng, Yongdong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: The growing demand for carbon neutrality has accelerated the deployment of photovoltaic (PV) systems, with centralized architectures becoming the preferred choice for megawatt-scale applications due to their simplicity, efficiency, and cost advantages. As the industry transitions from 1500-V to 2-kV dc systems, conventional inverter topologies encounter critical limitations: high-voltage devices suffers from significant switching losses at low operating voltages, while higher-level topologies increase device count, conduction loss, and system cost. To overcome these challenges, a variable-level (VL) active neutral-point clamped (ANPC) inverter is proposed, enabling efficiency optimization under variable dc-link voltages. This paper focuses on commutation behaviors analyzing and capacitor voltage control for the VL ANPC topology. A dedicated control strategy is developed to balance the side capacitor voltages and stabilize the central capacitor voltage under reconfigured dc-link capacitor voltages. Experimental and simulation results verify the proposed method, demonstrating enhanced efficiency and reliable capacitor voltage regulation for 2-kV PV inverter applications.

title: Deep Neural Network Watermarking to Detect Backdoor Attacks in Datasets Using Wet Paper Coding
authors: Annisa Putri, Gelar Budiman, Inung Wijayanto
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Emerging Trends in Information Systems and Informatics (ICETISI)
abstract: Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) in machine learning are vulnerable to backdoor attacks, where attackers insert unauthorized watermarks into the model to conceal specific patterns that can be exploited to manipulate predictions. These attacks can reduce model accuracy and cause misclassification when triggered by specially crafted inputs containing backdoors. To address this issue, this research proposes a watermarking method based on Wet Paper Coding (WPC), embedding watermarks directly into DNN model parameters, and using a Siamese Neural Network (SNN) for verification and backdoor attack detection. The watermark used is an email identifier, ensuring dataset integrity and ownership verification. The embedding process utilizes the Optimized Probabilistic Selection Strategy (OPSS) to select model parameters that have minimal impact on accuracy. WPC embeds the watermark by modifying "dry blocks" while preserving "wet blocks" to maintain model stability. After embedding, the watermark is extracted and verified using SNN, which compares it against registered email identifiers. If the extracted watermark does not match the authorized list, the model is flagged as potentially compromised by a backdoor attack.

title: Development of a Gel Urethra Model Simulator Using Agarose-PEG and Performance Evaluation of a Soft Growing Actuator for Urinary Catheter Insertion Assistance
authors: K. Kishino, R. Sasaki, F. Ito, H. Yamanaka, M. Komeya, T. Nakamura
publish: 2026 IEEE/SICE International Symposium on System Integration (SII)
abstract: This paper proposes a urinary catheter insertion assistance mechanism aimed at reducing pain and the risk of injury during insertion, as well as an agarose–PEG gel urethra model simulator for its performance evaluation. Conventional urinary catheterization has the drawback that friction against the urethral wall and impingement at curved sections can cause severe pain and tissue damage to patients. To address this, we focused on a soft growing actuator that can advance through a lumen without sliding its outer surface, and we developed a urinary catheter insertion assistance mechanism utilizing this actuator. In addition, we newly developed a gel-based urethra model simulator, made of agarose and PEG, capable of reproducing urethral length, diameter, curvature geometry, and Young’s modulus, and used it for performance evaluation of the proposed mechanism. Fundamental property tests confirmed that gel containing 2% agarose and 20% PEG achieved a Young’s modulus (~125 kPa) equivalent to that of the urethra and exhibited high toughness. In insertion experiments using the urethra model simulator, the proposed mechanism demonstrated stable extension and catheter traction even in models with curvature or straight-section stenosis. These results indicate that a urinary catheter insertion assistance mechanism employing a soft growing actuator has the potential to effectively reduce friction and alleviate pain inside the urethra.

title: Sonar Target Localization and Trajectory Based on Neural Network
authors: Runze Zhang, Mengyue Sun, Ziteng Huang
publish: 2025 6th International Symposium on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Communications (ISCEIC)
abstract: Underwater target localization and trajectory tracking are crucial for national defense, particularly for detecting enemy submarines and supporting antisubmarine missions. Traditional sonar systems using beamforming and tracking methods often suffer from limited accuracy and poor performance in complex underwater settings. This paper introduces an adaptive beamforming algorithm based on Radial Basis Function (RBF) neural networks, improving target bearing estimation with an accuracy of 88.89%. By further integrating the CenterNet detection algorithm with the OC-SORT tracking method, target motion estimation is enhanced, achieving an 89.3% detection rate. The proposed approaches were validated through Qiandao Lake trials, yielding high-resolution bearing images and reducing trajectory errors.

title: Benefits of Automatic Temperature Controller on Human Body and Maintaining Room Temperature
authors: Micko Stefanus, Nugraha Byru Sapphire, Vincentius Aaron, Mochammad Haldi Widianto
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Emerging Trends in Information Systems and Informatics (ICETISI)
abstract: In this modern era, the rise of earth’s temperature has played a great impact on human body temperature. High temperatures also increase humidity which leads to mold growth and other infrastructure damage. The authors have created a solution for this problem, an IoT-based device to control room temperature automatically in real-time. The device is able to turn the fan on and off the based on the set room temperature. This research result shows how room temperature can be maintained automatically using IoT device. Test concluded by the authors shows that the DHT22 sensor is able to detect surrounding temperature accurately. Allowing the relay to turn the fan on and off automatically when the room temperature is below or above 27 degrees Celsius to regulate the room temperature. Online form was also distributed to gather data from various people to determine the impact of room temperature on the human body which were not included in similar research. Based on the response collected, IoT based automation for controlling room temperature is a viable solution to maintain ideal room temperature. This IoT device efficiency can be increased further by switching the fan to a more advanced cooling device.

title: Disturbance Suppression Strategy of Intermediate DC-Bus Voltage for Two-stage Grid-connected Inverter
authors: Biying Ren, Xiangdong Sun, Jie Ma, Xinyu Zhang, Yanping Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: The intermediate DC-bus voltage in a two-stage grid-connected inverter is easily affected by disturbances caused by grid-side power fluctuations and switching between grid-connected and off-grid modes. Significant disturbances in the intermediate DC-bus voltage may degrade grid-connected power quality and adversely affect system stability. Therefore, effectively suppressing intermediate DC-bus voltage disturbances has become a critical research topic for two-stage grid-connected inverters. A two-stage grid-connected inverter composed of a dual-active-bridge (DAB) converter cascaded with a three-phase four-leg T-type three-level inverter is taken as the research object, a power feedforward control strategy based on closed-loop voltage control of the DAB converter is proposed to suppress the voltage disturbances on the intermediate DC bus. A mathematical model of the DAB converter under single-phase-shifting control is established, and the relationship between the intermediate DC-bus voltage and the instantaneous grid-connected power on the inverter side is analyzed. By introducing a power feedforward term to compensate for power deficits, the proposed strategy effectively mitigates intermediate DC-bus voltage disturbances and enhances the stability of the cascaded system. Simulation results validate the feasibility and correctness of the control strategy, demonstrating superior disturbance rejection performance compared to the system without power feedforward control.

title: A Novel High Efficiency Step-up DC auto-Transformer for DC Grid
authors: Shuxin Luo, Xuantong Zhou, Feng Li, Yanfeng Wang, Hao Yu, Renxin Yang, Jianqiao Zhou, Gang Shi, Jianwen Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Power Electronics and Application Symposium (PEAS)
abstract: This work presents a novel step-up auto-transformer architecture for direct current networks, engineered for high-efficiency, high-power interconnection of disparate DC grids. The topology integrates an energy transfer arm comprising a full-bridge submodule string, utilizing series-connectable thyristors as switching elements. To maximize the energy storage arm's dynamic controllability, a dedicated control methodology enables trapezoidal current profiling while guaranteeing thyristor commutation security. Comprehensive Matlab/Simulink simulations validate the proposed configuration's operational efficacy and control performance.
